head.supplied: November 12, 1895 ¶ My Dear Baron, ¶ ¶ I am leaving this afternoon for my farm, to stay there till the end of the week, so that further revision of the Elder plants will be deferred till my return. T...

div.p: From Ralph Tate
RB MSS M20, Library, Royal Botanic Gardens Melbourne.

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; text-align: end;

div.p: November 12, 1895

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt;

div.p: My Dear Baron,

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt;

div.p: I am leaving this afternoon for my farm, to stay there till the end of the week, so that further revision of the Elder plants will be deferred till my return. The interval will be devoted to the conclusion of the Geological Report of the Horn Expedition.

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt;

div.p: I have not yet touched the Myrtaceae, Compositae and Dampierae of the Elder Collection; but it is only in respect of the last that there remains much to be done.

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt;

div.p:
Examination-work
i.e. at the University of Adelaide. which commences on the 18th will break into any continuous leisure, which is so needful to accomplish much in the way of critical study, for about three weeks from that date

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 1.75in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: 0in;

div.p: Yrs sincerely

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 1.75in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: 0in;

div.p: Ralph Tate

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; text-align: center;

div.p:
Elder Expedition Plants.
There are two separate lists filed with the letter, each with the same heading, one of which (the first transcribed here) has been annotated by Tate in red ink: ' 7/11/95. R. Tate .' Every item on both lists has been marked by Tate in red or black ink, indicating that he went over them several times before sending them to M. The lists are early stages in the working up of the report by M and Tate on the botany of the Elder Expedition (B96.14.02).

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 0.4929in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.4929in;

div.p:
Daviesia
sp. 1. near Warangering.
WA. Many of the locality names that appear in Tate’s lists do not appear on modern gazeteers. The published report indicates whether they were in SA (which included NT at the time) or WA. Most appear to be features in the Victoria Desert, and the names to be those given to these features by the local Aboriginal people. By its calyx-teeth comes near D. pachylina

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 0.4929in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.4929in;

div.p:
Bossiaea Walkeri? You have the only specimen. Compare the foliage with that of Brachysema
aphyllum ; if my memory does not deceive me, I think this will prove the true location.

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 0.4929in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.4929in;
font-family: Geneva; margin-left: 0.3335in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.3335in; font-size: 9pt;
font-family: Geneva; margin-left: 0.3335in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.3335in; font-size: 9pt;

note.p: This entry is marked with a pencil line in the margin. Only one species of Phyllota is listed in B96.14.02, namely P. Luehmanni (p. 350), said to have been collected in the Victoria Desert, WA.

cell.style: padding-left: 0.075in; padding-right: 0.075in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt;

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt;

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt;

cell.style: padding-left: 0.075in; padding-right: 0.075in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt;

cell.style: padding-left: 0.075in; padding-right: 0.075in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt;

cell.style: padding-left: 0.075in; padding-right: 0.075in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;

cell.style: padding-left: 0.075in; padding-right: 0.075in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt;
font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 0.4929in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.4929in;

div.p:
Swainsonia
canescens ? I refer to S. phacoides .
The three ‘Swainsonia’ entries are bracketed in pencil.

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 0.4929in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.4929in;

div.p:
Kennedya
prostrata .
This entry is marked with a pencilled question mark in the margin. Has no flowers, but the pod is cylindrical; and therefore rightly named.

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 0.4929in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.4929in;

div.p:
Cassia
Sophera . Example unique in University Herbarium but is rightly named.

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 0.4929in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.4929in;

div.p:
Acacia
n. sp from between Red Kangaroo Hill and Yilgarn
Not identified. was reserved for future study by you

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 0.4929in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.4929in;

div.p:
Cryptandra
pungens ( v. nutans )? Victoria Desert.

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 0.4929in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.4929in;

div.p:
Cryptandra ( Spyridium ) off complicata ? Victorian Desert. I cannot refer to description of S. rotundifolia my material is in very indifferent condition
The Cryptandra are bracketed in the margin.

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 0.4929in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.4929in;

div.p:
Didiscus
glaucifolius (with slight variation from typical examples) Is certainly right. New for W.A.

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 0.4929in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.4929in;

div.p:
Didiscus
coeruleus unique example from near Esperance Bay.
WA. This determination does not admit of doubt
The Didicus are bracketed in the margin.

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 0.4929in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.4929in;

div.p: Hydrocotyle aff muriculata = H. trachycarpa , without granules on the fruitlets.

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 0.4929in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.4929in;

div.p:
Actinotus
leucocephalus . Dwarfed state, tallest specimens attaining to four inches.

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 0.4929in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.4929in;

div.p:
Haloragis
odontocarpa . Specimen with out fruit, but the foliage and habit comparable with an authentic example from Darling River
NSW?

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 0.4929in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.4929in;

div.p:
Haloragis
sp ., near Barrow Ramge is indeterminable, probably H. Gossei

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 0.4929in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.4929in;

div.p:
Haloragis
confertifolia the nearest approach which I can offer

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 0.4929in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.4929in;

div.p:
Haloragis
aculeolata . Your specimen is unique
The Haloragis are bracketed in the margin.

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 0.4929in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.4929in;

div.p: Exocarpos ? sp. Victoria Desert. The crowded leaves suggest E. odorata

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 0.4929in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.4929in;

div.p: Canthium sp. Victoria Desert. The flowers are like those of C. lucidum , but the shape of leaves is very different and so also, apparently, the venation

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 0.4929in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.4929in;

div.p:
Opercularia
spermacocea , from Yerdanie,
WA. is I think rightly named; but with it from Victoria Desert is

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 0.4929in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.4929in;

div.p: O. aff echinocephala differing there from by sessile leaves and the flowers stalked above the last leaves.

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 0.4929in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.4929in;

div.p:
Scaevola
parvifolia Is I consider correct

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 0.4929in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.4929in;

div.p:
Scaevola
anchusiaefolia ?
Scaevola anch usaefol ia? Is closely allied to S. depauperata , from which it differs by larger flowers, acute sepal-points, and hairy style.

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 0.4929in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.4929in;

div.p:
Scaevola
fasiculata
Scaevola
f ascic ulata ?
Is I think correct.

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 0.4929in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.4929in;

div.p:
Goodenia
lamprosperma ? May be a state of G. heteromera .

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 0.4929in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.4929in;

div.p:
Goodenia
cycloptera from Warrina
SA? is rightly named; but the Barrow Range
WA. plant is doubtful, as the flowers are not spurred.

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 0.4929in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.4929in;

div.p:
Goodenia
Mitchelli
G. Mitchellii ?
from Arcoeillinna Well
SA. seems a typical form of G. heterochila

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 0.4929in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.4929in;

div.p:
Goodenia
aff Mueckiana
G. Mu eckean a? from Barrow Range & Camp 50 seems to be a varietal form of G. heteroclita .

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 0.4929in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.4929in;

div.p:
Goodenia
aff sepalosa from Macdonnell Range
NT. with viscid leaves, which you altered to G. heterochila , is a distinct species. The fruits are oblong-cylindric, the dissepiment fully half the length of fruit, seeds lenticular, small, with a narrow callous border.
MS annotation by Tate in red: 'Your approbation is early desired. R. Tate.'

cell.style: padding-left: 0.075in; padding-right: 0.075in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt;

cell.style: padding-left: 0.075in; padding-right: 0.075in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt;
font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 0.4929in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.4929in;

div.p:
Goodenia
heteromera . Is I think correct.

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 0.4929in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.4929in;

div.p:
Goodenia
hirsuta . Arkaringa Valley
SA. & Barrow Range. Though it recalls G. hederacea , yet I think this new species might be transferred to
Catosperma
. Ripe fruits not seen; ovary 2-celled; 10 ovules in each cell, mostly ascending, some apparently pendulous, attached throughout the whole length of the complete septum; stigma-cover shortly 2-cleft

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 0.4929in; margin-right: 0in; text-align: center; text-indent: -0.4929in;

div.p: Elder Expedition Plants.

cell.style: padding-left: 0.075in; padding-right: 0.075in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt;

cell.p: simile . Is right, having globose fruits

cell.style: padding: 0in; border: none;

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 0.4929in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.4929in;

div.p:
Dicrastylis
spp. =
Breweria rosea

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 0.4929in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.4929in;

div.p:
Stemodia
viscosa is correctly named.

cell.style: padding-left: 0.075in; padding-right: 0.075in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt;

cell.style: padding-left: 0.075in; padding-right: 0.075in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt;

cell.p: Wilkieana , a variety with small flowers and very silky pubescence

cell.style: padding-left: 0.075in; padding-right: 0.075in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; text-align: center;

cell.style: padding-left: 0.075in; padding-right: 0.075in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt;

cell.p:
Baxteri right for S.A. and Victoria; but the specimens from Gnarlbine & Knutsford
Both WA. are perhaps

cell.style: padding-left: 0.075in; padding-right: 0.075in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; text-align: center;

cell.style: padding-left: 0.075in; padding-right: 0.075in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt;
font-family: Geneva; margin-left: 0.3335in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.3335in; font-size: 9pt;
font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 0.4929in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.4929in;

div.p:
Teucrium
sessiliflorum . Right, has narrower leaf-segments than ordinarily.

cell.style: padding-left: 0.075in; padding-right: 0.075in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; text-align: center;

cell.style: padding-left: 0.075in; padding-right: 0.075in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: -0.1736in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: 0.1346in;

cell.p:
grandiflorum .
Teucrium grandiusculum? agrees with type.

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 0.4929in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.4929in;

div.p:
Microcorys
sp. the unique example is in your possession

cell.style: padding-left: 0.075in; padding-right: 0.075in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt;

cell.style: padding-left: 0.075in; padding-right: 0.075in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt;

cell.p: tomentosa n. sp. not attachable to any described species

cell.style: padding-left: 0.075in; padding-right: 0.075in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; text-align: center;

cell.style: padding-left: 0.075in; padding-right: 0.075in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt;

cell.p: cyanea , var. with narrow entire leaves, cymes reduced to few flowers.

cell.style: padding-left: 0.075in; padding-right: 0.075in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; text-align: center;

cell.style: padding-left: 0.075in; padding-right: 0.075in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt;

cell.p: corymbosa v. sericiflora . Seemingly one or the other.

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 0.4929in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.4929in;

div.p:
Heliotropium
paniculatum = H. tenuifolium , paniculate form of (no flowers in my specimen.

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 0.4929in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.4929in;

div.p:
Chloanthes
Drummondi
Name not in APNI. = loxocarpa from Victoria Desert. Cannot arrive at any satisfactory rest. Cor. 5-lobed, calyx deeply 5-cleft, stamens 4.

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 0.4929in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.4929in;

div.p:
Chloanthes ? n. sp. near Southern Cross.
WA. Cor. unequally 5-lobed, calyx deeply divided; stamens 4, 2 long & 2 short; anthers devaricate ovary lobeless; fruit with a hollow base separating into two 1-seeded fruitlets, dissepiment incomplete above.

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 0.4929in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.4929in;

div.p:
Newcastlia
n. sp . off Dixoni Style shortly bilobed

cell.style: padding-left: 0.075in; padding-right: 0.075in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt;

cell.style: padding-left: 0.075in; padding-right: 0.075in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 36pt;

cell.style: padding-left: 0.075in; padding-right: 0.075in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt;

cell.p: I see no reason to alter these names

cell.style: padding-left: 0.075in; padding-right: 0.075in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt;

cell.style: padding-left: 0.075in; padding-right: 0.075in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;

font-family: Geneva; margin-left: 0.3335in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.3335in; font-size: 9pt;
font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 0.4929in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.4929in;

div.p:
Thysanotus
arbuscula the species name preferable to dichotomus

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 0.4929in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.4929in;

div.p:
Bartlingia
grandiflora Agrees with description

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt;

div.p:
Arthropodium
Preissii You have the unique example

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 0.4929in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.4929in;

div.p:
Xerotes
fimbriatus
Xerotes fimbriata ?
Seemingly right; flowers bisexual in all examined

div.p:
Restiaceae
. The four species of this Order beat me, firstly I have

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt;

div.p:
little knowledge of our Australian species, and secondly three species are representing
sic. by male flowers only. I framed a synopsis of the genera based on the androccium, but it was not workable. Species no. 2. has male & female flowers in the same spikelet, and in habit would seem to be a sp. of
Ecideicolea
;
Ecdeicolea? but there are 2 bracteoles under each flower as in
Anarthria
. However there is only one ovule
There is a small pencil sketch here: 95-11-12a_image01.jpg in the ovulary, as the result of three observations by slight crushing under the microscope. I enclose some separated flowers.
Sp. 1. may be Loxocarya has been deleted, presumably by Tate.

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt;

cell.p: fulvus . Is right not included in your set

cell.p:
rotundus . based on the foliage and edible corms & compared with the Finke
Finke River, NT.
plant.

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 0.4929in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.4929in;

div.p:
Fimbristylis
communis . nut not seen, but otherwise correct.

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 0.4929in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.4929in;

div.p:
Isolepis
cartilagineus .
Isolepis cartilaginea? I have no doubt about

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 0.4929in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.4929in;

div.p:
Lepidosperma
n. sp . (Section Tereticaules) from Mt Ilbillee.
SA. This is certainly new for S.A I cannot attach it with any described species from W.A though it is seemingly near to leptostachyum

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 0.4929in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.4929in;

div.p:
Lepidosperma
leptophyllum ? Karoling. Is like semiteres , but the stems are more compressed, it is probably L. gracile

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 0.4929in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.4929in;

div.p:
Lepidosperma
gracile , Fraser Range.
WA. I consider correct

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 0.4929in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.4929in;

div.p:
Lepidosperma
Drummondii & L. resinosum = L. Drummondii , because of the acute glumes. The fewer sterile flowers, broader stems & loose panicle separate it from viscidum

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 0.4929in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.4929in;

div.p:
Panicum
effusum . A unique ex.
example? not sent, but is rightly named

pectinata is unique in your set
